tema1.question: What is the purpose of the OSI model in networking?

answers.answer: To define an architecture for network protocols.
To establish a framework for software development.
To specify the physical network infrastructure.

tema1.question: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for end-to-end communication and provides services like encryption and decryption?
What is the primary function of the Network Layer in the OSI model?
What layer does the ARP protocol operate in and what is its main purpose?

answers.answer: Layer-1, map IP addresses to MAC addresses.
Layer-3, resolve domain names to IP addresses.

tema1.question: Which layer does a router operate in, and what is its main function?

answers.answer: Layer-2, connects devices within the same network.
Layer-2, forwards packets between different networks.
Layer-3, connects devices within the same network.
Layer-3, forwards packets between different networks.

tema1.question: What layer does the ICMP protocol operate in, and what is the purpose of the protocol?
Which of the following is only a layer-2 device in an Ethernet-based computer network?
What is the purpose of DHCP protocol in a LAN (Local Area Network)?

answers.answer: To dynamically manage assignment of layer-2 addresses (MAC) to hosts.
To dynamically manage assignment of layer-3 addresses (IP) to hosts.
To dynamically manage assignment of layer-4 addresses (ports) to hosts.

tema1.question: Which protocol in the TCP/IP stack is responsible for ensuring that data packets are delivered reliably and in order?
What layer in the TCP/IP model does the UDP protocol operate in and what is its main purpose?
Which of the following protocols belong to the Internet layer in the TCP/IP model?
When used for computer communications, what is the main benefit of packet switched networks?

answers.answer: It does not require a call setup phase prior to data transmission.
It provides a dedicated physical path for data transmission.
It ensures that packets always arrive in the order they are transmitted.

tema1.question: When considering computer networks, a protocol defines:

answers.answer: The message types and the message format that devices exchange.
Only the message types that devices exchange.
Only the message format that devices exchange.

tema1.question: What is the main organization that standardizes Internet protocols in RFC (Request for Comments) documents?
In the TCP/IP model, what is the name of the data unit exchanged by hosts at the transport layer?
In an IP network, what does the RTT (Round-Trip Time) measure?

answers.answer: The time it takes for a packet to travel from the source to the destination, including the transmission, propagation and queueing times.
The time it takes for a packet to travel from the source to the destination and for the acknowledgement to return back, including the transmission, propagation and queueing times.
The time it takes for a packet to travel from the source to the destination, including the time to setup the circuit, the time to transmit the data, and the time to tear-down the circuit.

tema1.question: In an IPv4 network, what is the length (i.e., number of bits) of the network mask of a Class B address?

In an IPv4 network, in addition to the host address (i.e., 147.83.77.12), what other information has to be configured at the network layer to be able to send packets to another host from a different network (i.e., 8.8.8.8.)?

answers.answer: The network mask and the gateway address.
The network address, the gateway address and the address of the DNS server.
The address of the DHCP server.

tema1.question: What of the following IPv4 subnets is used by ISPs (Internet Service Providers) to offer the CG-NAT service?
What field in the IPv4 header is used to identify the transport layer protocol that is being carried by the packet (i.e., TCP, UDP or ICMP)?
What of the following services is provided by UDP (User Datagram Protocol) at the transport layer?
At the transport layer, what protocol and port number does the DNS service use?
At the transport layer, what is the length of the source and destination port which allow to multiplex the applications running on the same host?
At the transport layer, what is the total length of the UDP header?
Which of the following network protocols does NOT use TCP for reliable delivery of data?
When establishing a connection with a remote host, TCP uses the 3-way handshake mechanism. What bits of the TCP header are used by the sender (S) and the receiver (R) during the 3-way handshake?

answers.answer: S: SYN, R: ACK, S: ACK.
S: SYN, R: SYN+ACK, S: ACK.
S: SYN, R: SYN, S: FIN.
S: SYN, R: SYN+ACK, S: ACK.

tema1.question: During the slow start phase of the credit-based flow control mechanism, TCP x the y every z.

answers.answer: x = doubles, y = congestion window, z = RTT.
x = increments by one unit, y = packet buffer, z = second.
x = increments by one unit, y = congestion window, z = RTT.
x = doubles, y = congestion window, z = second.

tema1.question: The original Ethernet standard, developed in 1972 at Xerox PARC for Local Area Networks (LANs), provided a data transfer speed of x Mbps over a y cable using a z topology.

In an Ethernet network, what is the equipment that isolates the collision domain in each physical port, effectively creating a star topology and ensuring that transmissions from different stations cannot collide?
In an Ethernet network, what is the length of the MAC address?

A host has a MAC address (ab:cd:ef:12:34:56), as well as an IPv4 address (192.168.100.10/24) and a gateway address (192.168.100.1) configured. If the host executes ’ping 8.8.8.8’, what will be the target protocol (IP) and target hardware (MAC) addresses of the ARP Request message (i.e., not the Ethernet frame)? Assume the ARP table is initially empty.
A router receives an IP packet with TTL=1. What is the type and code of the ICMP message that the router will send back to the packet source?

answers.answer: The router will send an ICMP packet of Type=0 and Code=0 (Echo reply).
The router will send an ICJMP packet of Type=3 and Code=3 (Destination unreachable).
The router will forward the IP packet to the destination without sending an ICMP packet.

tema1.question: If a router fails to resolve the data-link layer address of a target host using the ARP protocol to deliver a frame (i.e., direct deliver), what ICMP message does it send back to the origin?

answers.answer: The router will send an ICMP packet of Type=0 and Code=0 (Echo reply).
The router will send an ICMP packet of Type=5 and Code=0 (Redirect).
The router will send an ICMP packet of Type=11 and Code=0 (Time exceeded).

tema1.question: In IPv4 networks, what protocol is used to automatically configure the host address, network mask, gateway address and DNS servers address, as well as other configuration parameters?
What layer of the TCP/IP model does the DHCP protocol operate in? What protocol and source port does the DHCP client use to send packets to the server?

A host has the 01:02:03:04:05:06 MAC address and the DHCP server has the 0a:0b:0c:0d:0e:0f MAC address. In the DHCP allocation process, what is the destination MAC address of the Ethernet header that the host and the server use to send packets?

A host sends a DHCP Discover request to acquire the network address and mask from a DHCP server with MAC address 01:02:03:04:05:06 and IP address 192.168.100.254. What is the destination address of the packet at the data-link layer (i.e., MAC address) and the network layer (i.e., IP address) that the host sends the packet to?
If a LAN (Local Area Network) has two DHCP servers operating at the same time, what field of the DHCP packet header is used to distinguish to which server is a client talking to?
When a host requests an IP address using DHCP, what is the message that it sends back to the DHCP server to confirm the address that the DHCP server has offered?
In addition to the IP address, what other information is provided by the DHCP server to ensure that the host can execute the ’ping google.com’ command and get a response?

answers.answer: Only the network mask and the DNS servers.
Only the network gateway and the network mask.
Only the network gateway and the DNS servers.

tema1.question: Your computer has the following EUI-48 address: 1a:2b:3c:4d:5e:6f. If you are given the following IPv6 prefix 2000:abc::/32 in the dead subnet, what is the link-local address of your host?
Your AS is assigned the IPv6 network prefix 2000:abc:def::/56. How many subnetworks (i.e., sites) can you have? How many hosts can each subnetwork have?
In an IPv6 network, which protocol is used to match the IPv6 address and the physical address (i.e., MAC address) of a host to enable delivering frames locally?
Which of the following fields have been removed in the IPv6 header when compared to the IPv4 header? Do not consider IPv6 header extensions.
The size of an IPv6 address is:
You are given the following IPv6 address: 2001:0000:8489:0000:0000:0AAB:0038:0001. Which of the following is the correct short representation of the IPv6 address?
What are the two parts that form a global unique IPv6 address?
What prefix is used for IPv6 multicast addresses?
What is the IPv6 multicast address of All-nodes in link-local scope?
Which of the following IPv6 network prefixes is used to send packets over a local network?

tema2.question: What is the international organization that is responsible for assigning Internet resources (i.e., AS numbers and IP address ranges) world-wide?
What routing protocol is used to interconnect Autonomous Systems (AS) on the Internet? What transport layer protocol and port does it use?

A company wishes to announce its own IP network prefix to the Internet using various service providers. What kind of IP address prefix does it have to request to the RIR? What connectivity model would it be best to ensure connectivity in case one of the service providers fail?
What is the RIR in charge of providing Internet resources in North America?
In a router, what plane is responsible to fill in the routing table based on the information provided by the network administrator or neighbour routers using routing protocols?
What is the algorithm executed in the router forwarding plane to determine which interface a packet has to be forwarded to based on its destination IP address?

In a router, for each destination network, which is the table that contains the addresses of the next hop (i.e., the address of the router to which the packets have to be forwarded to) and the exit interface of the packet?

For the same destination network, which of the following mechanisms to fill in the routing table has the smallest administrative distance and, thus, is preferred by the router, as it provides the most reliable information?
Which of the following routing protocol families are used for routing within an Autonomous System?
Which of the following routing protocols is NOT an IGP (Interior Gateway Protocol) (although it can be used as one in certain scenarios)?

answers.answer: None, all mentioned protocols are IGPs.

tema2.question: What routing algorithm does RIP use to compute the best path between two given points in a network?
What transport layer protocol and source/destination port do RIP routers use to communicate?
What communication model do routers that execute RIPv1 use to communicate between them?
What is the main limitation of the RIP routing protocol when dealing with large networks?

answers.answer: The network diameter is limited to 15 hops.
It is prone to routing loops due to the slow convergence time.
The metric (i.e., number of hops) cannot be changed.
All the above answers are known limitations of RIP.

tema2.question: What is the main benefit of RIPv2 when compared to RIPv1?

answers.answer: It is no longer limited to a maximum number of hops (i.e., 15).
It is no longer limited by the use of classful routing (i.e., class A, B or C).
It is no longer limited by the default administrative distance (i.e., 120).
All the above answers are correct.

tema2.question: The RIPv2 protocol supports neighbor authentication by:

answers.answer: Setting the AFI field in the header to 0xFFFF.
Setting the Command field in the header to 0xFFFF.
Setting the Unused field in the header to 0xFFFF.

tema2.question: Which of the protection mechanisms introduced in RIPv2 to reduce convergence time and the chance of routing loops is based on the principle ’Not advertising routes through the same interface from which the router has learned them’?
With respect to RIPv1, that only supports classful routing, which field is added in the RIPv2 protocol header to support VLSM and CIDR?
Which RIP timer is used by the router to determine when to send routing updates to neighbor routers?
OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) is an x routing protocol based on the principle of y routing using the z routing algorithm.
What transport layer protocol does OSPF use to communicate neighbor routers?

answers.answer: OSPF uses UDP as the transport layer protocol.
OSPF uses TCP as the transport layer protocol.
OSPF uses ICMP as the transport layer protocol.
None, OSPF is transported directly over IP using protocol 89.

tema2.question: If a router learns two routes to the same destination network (i.e., 147.83.0.0/16), one via RIP and the other via OSPF, which one will become active in the routing table and will be used to forward packets?

answers.answer: The router learned via RIP, as it has a higher administrative distance (120).
The router learned via OSPF, as it has a smaller administrative distance (110).
The router learned via RIP, since it has a smaller administrative distance (110).
Both routes will become active, since the administrative distance is not used for such purpose.

tema2.question: The metric that OSPF uses to determine which path between two networks is better than the other is based on...

answers.answer: ...the delay of the slowest link in the path between both networks.
...the bandwidth of the fastest link in the path between both networks.
...the number of hops (i.e., routers) in the path between both networks, as it is done in RIP.
...a combination of the number of hops and the cost of each link in the path between both networks.

tema2.question: An OSPF router has a RouterID = 1.1.1.1 that is unique. In which state is the OSPF state machine when a HELLO message is received from a neighbor router that contains the same RouterID (i.e., 1.1.1.1)?
OSPF operates in a broadcast network (i.e., Ethernet) with 6 routers. Thanks to selecting a DR and a BDR router, how many adjacencies will these routers form?
In OSPF, which packet type is used by routers to send the missing content of the LSDB to neighbor routers?
Which is of the following is a benefit of using OSPF with respect to RIP?

answers.answer: It converges faster and better avoids creating routing loops since all routers have a complete view of the network topology.
It no longer requires periodic updates between routers, only triggered updates upon topology changes (i.e. link or router failure).
It is no longer limited by the maximum number of hops since all routers have a complete view of the network topology.
All the above answers are benefits of OSPF with respect RIP.

tema2.question: Which routing protocol is used for routing between ASs? What is the routing principle that it is based upon?
What is the metric that BGP uses to determine which is best path between two AS on the Internet?
The BGP state machine has 6 states. In which state does BGP send an OPEN message and waits for the response of its peer?

When the connection between two BGP peers is established, which kind of message types do routers exchange to add new routes (i.e., advertise) or remove (i.e., withdraw) routers that are no longer available?
What are the BGP attributes that all routers have to support, are always present, and are propagated globally?
Which of the following BGP attributes is NOT a well-known and mandatory?
Which of the following BGP attributes is a well-known and mandatory attribute, and includes the sequence of ASNs a network prefix is propagated through?
What field in the BGP open message header indicates how long a neighbor router can keep the BGP session open without receiving messages from its neighbor?
What kind of BGP attribute is the MED?

Which mechanism based on public-key infrastructure has been implemented on Internet routers to validate the origin of the BGP announcements (i.e., AS number and IP network prefixes) and reduce the chances of prefix leaks and hijacking?

A router has the following entries in its routing table. If the router receives an IP packet with destination address 185.133.89.100, to which next-hop address and interface will it forward the packet to? Despite not being shown for simplicity, assume that the next-hop addresses and interfaces can be resolved by the router.

A router has the following entries in its routing table. If the router receives an IP packet with destination address 185.132.89.144, to which next-hop address and interface will it forward the packet to? Despite not being shown for simplicity, assume that the next-hop addresses and interfaces can be resolved by the router.

A router has the following entries in its routing table. If the router receives an IP packet with destination address 185.132.89.120, to which next-hop address and interface will it forward the packet to? Despite not being shown for simplicity, assume that the next-hop addresses and interfaces can be resolved by the router.

tema3.question: In a .......... network, the QoS is guaranteed because a path is established along the network before data transmission and resources are reserved.
What quantitative mechanism is used to measure the perceived quality of a telecommunication service by users?
The .......... is the variation of the arrival time between two consecutive packets.
When transporting a real-time service (i.e., videoconference) over a packet switched network, a playback buffer is able to compensate for:
When a network application transmits packets of the same size and at the same rate, we say that the application is of type:
What QoS mechanism used in packet switched networks is based on resource reservation?
In the IntServ model, what protocol is used to reserve resources along the path using PATH and RESV messages?
What field of the IPv4 header is used in the DiffServ model to mark packets with QoS requirements?

answers.answer: None of the above, QoS on the Internet is marked at the Ethernet header.

tema3.question: In the DiffServ model, which of the following application types has more priority?
What queue management mechanism is used by routers to randomly discard packets proportionally to the number of packets waiting in the queue?
In a router, what is the name of the mechanism used to determine which queue has to be serviced next (i.e., transmit a packet from that queue)?
How would you classify an application that can adapt to available bandwidth and is not sensitive to delay/jitter, but cannot tolerate packet loss? Give an example of such application.
What is defined as the product between capacity and delay, also known as the BDP (Bandwidth-Delay Product)?
In a router, what is the name of the mechanism used to determine which queue has to be serviced next?
When transporting a real-time service like a videoconference, what component is able to compensate for jitter and various network delays?
What is a VBR (Variable Bit Rate) application?

answers.answer: An application where packets have different sizes and can be sent at different rates.
An application that does not tolerate packet loss.
An application that generates packets of the same size at the same rate.
An application that requires a prior establishment of a circuit.

tema3.question: Which of the following applications is considered "inelastic," meaning it has strict requirements for delay and jitter but can tolerate some packet loss?

A router in a DiffServ network receives a packet. First, it examines the packet’s DSCP field to sort it into a "high priority" queue. Next, it decides to send a packet from this queue before a packet in the "low priority" queue. What are these two mechanisms called, respectively?
What is a fundamental scalability limitation of the IntServ (Integrated Services) model that the DiffServ (Differentiated Services) model was designed to solve?

answers.answer: IntServ requires routers to maintain state and manage resource reservations (using RSVP) for every single application flow, which does not scale in a large network.
IntServ only provides best-effort service and cannot guarantee QoS.
IntServ cannot be used for inelastic applications like voice or video.
IntServ uses the IPv4 header’s TTL field , while DiffServ uses the more efficient DSCP field.

tema3.question: What is the primary advantage of using the RED (Random Early Detection) queue management mechanism over Tail Drop?

answers.answer: RED guarantees that no packets are ever dropped, while Tail Drop does.

Tail Drop only drops packets when the queue is 100% full, causing many TCP flows to slow down simultaneously (global sync). RED starts randomly dropping packets before the queue is full to signal congestion more gracefully.
RED prioritizes high-priority traffic (like voice) using DSCP, while Tail Drop is best-effort.
Tail Drop drops packets from the front of the queue, while RED drops from the tail.

tema4.question: A LAN has two routers working in parallel using VRRP to increase gateway availability. Router 1 has MTBF=100 hours and MTTR=5 hours, Router 2 has MTBF=1000 hours and MTTR=24 hours. What is the total availability of the system?
What type and IP address do VRRP routers use to determine which is the master and the backup router?
What is the term that describes the time between two consecutive equipment failures?
A pair of VRRP routers is configured with VRID=200. What MAC address is used by VRRP routers to send packets?
What is the default hello and hold timer for VRRP?
An equipment has a measured downtime per year of 60 minutes. What is the availability level?
During which period of equipment lifetime is the failure rate λ constant?
Which of the following is NOT a routing protocol?
What mechanism does a VRRP router use to advertise the IP/MAC pair of the virtual gateway to hosts?
What is the priority of the default VRRP master?

When the VRRP router with the highest priority becomes available after a failure, what is the operation mode of the protocol that allows a VRRP router with lower priority to continue acting as the VRRP master?
Which layer of the OSI model do firewalls primarily operate at?
Which firewall type does not retain information about the state of network connections?
What is the device in charge of logging rejected packets entering or leaving the network?
Which is the firewall type that includes a state machine to track the status of connections passing through it to determine if a packet is allowed or not?
What is an application layer gateway for HTTP incoming traffic?
With respect to packet filters, which of the following sentences is incorrect when considering traffic logging?

answers.answer: It can track the source and destination address of the packet.
It can track the source and destination port of the packet.
It can track the connection state of the packet.
None of the above sentences is incorrect.

tema4.question: Which difference is correct when comparing plain packet filters with stateful packet filters?

answers.answer: The quality and quantity of the audit trail.
The requirement to include rules for response traffic in the rule set.
The session handling of HTTP sessions.

tema4.question: What is/are the difference(s) between the white listing and the black listing approach of firewalls?

answers.answer: The default behaviour if no other rule matches is different.
They relate to different network interfaces of a firewall.
The choice is very important for the performance of the firewall.

tema4.question: Which statement(s) is / are correct when describing the functionality of a packet filtering firewall?

answers.answer: The order of filtering rules never makes a difference on the filter results.
The order of filtering rules does make a difference on the filter results.
The order of filtering rules only makes a difference on the filter results for rules which PASS traffic.

tema4.question: What types of information can be processed by a plain packet filtering firewall for deciding on whether traffic may pass the firewall or not?

answers.answer: HTTP method used for an HTTP request (e.g. GET or POST)
User name which is being used for an SSH connection.
Source and destination port and address of a TCP communication.

tema4.question: What does the abbreviation “PAP” stand for?

answers.answer: Packet Filter – Application Level Gateway – Packet Filter

tema4.question: What can the audit trail of a firewall be used for?

answers.answer: Protecting the users that access the firewall to change its rules.
Detecting MAC spoofing attacks in the Local Area Network.
Monitoring legitimate traffic, which is of special interest in terms of security.

tema4.question: Which limitations are correct for a packet filtering firewall?

answers.answer: No security for applications – once communication to an application is allowed, the application cannot be protected anymore.
No analysis of traffic higher than TCP/IP layer 4.
No checks of communication regarding its compliance to specifications.

tema4.question: Which properties are correct when describing the functionality of an application level gateway (ALG)?

answers.answer: The ALG is a synonym for a packet filtering firewall.
The ALG ensures that end-to-end communication between browser and server is never intercepted.
An ALG is user independent – it never discriminates traffic based on the initiator.

tema4.question: Regarding Next Generation Firewalls, which of the following statements is false?

answers.answer: Packet filters have no added value anymore since attackers know their functioning.
More and more traffic is being communicated via HTTP(s) in the Internet.
Static filter rules alone do not address the modern threat situation.

tema4.question: Given the ACL, who will be able to connect to the web server at 147.83.100.1 and retrieve a website?

answers.answer: Yes, all hosts on the Internet will be able to access the web server.
Yes, but only hosts originating from the 147.83.0.0/24 prefix.
Yes, but only hosts using the UDP protocol to communicate with the web server.
No, communication with the web server from the Internet will not be possible.

tema4.question: Given the ACL, will host 147.83.0.1 receive the ICMP request from 83.100.10.1, and will the ICMP reply return?

answers.answer: Yes, both the request and response will go through.
Yes, the request is received but the response does not return.
No, the request will not be received.
It is impossible to determine from the ACL.

tema5.question: Which DNS record type maps hostnames to IPv6 addresses?
Which transport layer protocol and port does the DNS service use?
Which DNS query allows to retrieve the host and the domain name from an IP address?
Which DNS query is used to retrieve the host address (i.e., IPv4 or IPv6) of the DNS servers responsible for a given domain name?
What international and non-profit organization is responsible for managing the DNS service worldwide?
In which type of DNS query does the server return the IP address of the DNS server that it thinks can resolve the query?
How many different DNS root servers are deployed worldwide?
In which kind of DNS query does the resolver only make one query to get the reply?
What is the source of the DNS hierarchy?
What is the maximum length of a DNS label and of a full domain name?
When performing a reverse DNS resolution for given IPv4 address (i.e., 147.83.1.1), what is the type of the request and the domain name used in the query?
Which DNS record type is used to specify the email server responsible for accepting email messages on behalf of a domain?
What is the primary purpose of the TTL (Time To Live) field in a DNS record?

answers.answer: It indicates the time it takes for a packet to reach the server
It specifies how long a resolver or cache should store the record before discarding it
It determines the maximum number of hops a DNS query can make

tema5.question: Before the invention of DNS, name resolution was handled by a single text file stored locally on every computer. What is the name of this file?
While the 'A' record maps a hostname to an IPv4 address, which record explicitly maps a hostname to an IPv6 address?
Which of the following refers to a domain name that specifies its exact location in the tree hierarchy of the DNS, usually ending with a dot (e.g., www.google.com.)?
In the domain name tecnocampus.cat, what type of Top Level Domain (TLD) is .cat?
Although DNS primarily uses UDP, in which specific scenario is the TCP protocol explicitly required?

answers.answer: When performing a standard recursive query
When performing a Zone Transfer (AXFR) between servers
When the client is using a mobile network

tema5.question: Which DNS record type contains administrative information about the zone, such as the email address of the administrator, the serial number, and refresh intervals?
If a user queries a local DNS server for nonexistent.tecnocampus.cat and the domain does not exist, what response code does the server return?
Which DNS extension provides cryptographic authentication of data to ensure that DNS records have not been forged or manipulated?
Which of the following describes the "Anycast" routing technique used by Root DNS servers?

answers.answer: A single server handles all requests worldwide
Requests are sent to all 13 root servers simultaneously
Multiple servers share the same IP address, and the network routes the query to the geographically closest server

tema5.question: If you want to create an alias for an existing domain name (e.g., making ftp.example.com point to www.example.com), which record type should you use?

answers.answer: A or AAA, depending on if you use IPv4 or IPv6

tema5.question: In the context of a DNS header, what is the function of the "Recursion Desired" (RD) flag?

answers.answer: It tells the server to accept any DNS query, regardless of the query type (i.e., recursive or iterative)
It instructs the server to query other servers if it does not have the answer in its cache
It indicates that the response is from an authoritative source

tema5.question: What differentiates an authoritative name server from a recursive resolver?

answers.answer: The authoritative server holds the actual DNS records for a domain, while the recursive resolver looks up the data for the client
The recursive resolver holds the actual records, while the authoritative server asks questions
Authoritative servers only use TCP; recursive resolvers only use UDP
There is no difference; they are synonyms

tema5.question: Which file on a GNU/Linux system is typically used to configure the IP addresses of the recursive DNS servers (resolvers) that the system should use?

tema6.question: Which is the version of the HTTP protocol that uses persistent connections by default?
What is the name of the first line of the HTTP request message?
What HTTP method leaves the body of the message empty?
Regarding the conditional GET mechanism, which of the following sentences is not correct?

answers.answer: It imposes conditions on the objects to be requested.
It limits the number of response from a server.
It helps to keep a cache upto date.
None of the above sentences is correct.

tema6.question: Which of the following is present in both an HTTP request line and a HΤΤΡ status line?
What field of the URI indicates which client/server program to used in order to retrieve a document?
What is the markup language used to create web pages?
What kind of mechanism does the HTTP protocol use to transport information between the client and the server (and viceversa)?

answers.answer: Depends on the kind of data that it has to transmit.

tema6.question: In the context of an HTTP transaction using basic access authentication (i.e., using the Authorization: Basic <credentials> header, where <credencials> is <user: password>, why is Base64 used to transmit the credentials string (i.e., <user: password>)?

answers.answer: It is used for data encryption, ensuring that user credentials cannot be captured despite the fact that HTTP transmits data in plain text.
It is used for data authentication, ensuring that user credentials are transmitted from a computer that is trusted despite the fact taht HTTP transmits data in plain text.
It used for data encoding, ensuring that non-HTTP compatible characters in the user and password are transmitted as HTTP-compatible characters.

tema6.question: Which of the following connection types requires one TCP connection for each interaction (i.e., request/response) with the HTTP server?
An HTTP request message always contains:

answers.answer: A header and a request line.
A header, a status line and a body.

tema6.question: What is the protocol and the default port for an HTTPS connection?
What is the international non-profit organization responsible for standardizing the HTTP protocol?
Which of the following HTTP methods was not supported by HTTP/1.0?
What is the status code used by HTTP to indicate server-side errors to the client?
The following text "TecnoCampus" is encoded using UTF-8 (i.e., 8 bits/character). What is the resulting Base64-encoded representation of the text when sent over an HTTP response?

When using Base64 to encode a binary file (i.e., an image) the resulting text occupies more space than the original file. Assuming the binary file occupies 300 bytes, what is size of the resulting text and the expansion rate (i.e., the resulting number of bytes divided by the original number of bytes) of Base64 encoding?

answers.answer: The resulting text occupies 300 bytes, which corresponds to an expansion rate of 25%.
The resulting text occupies 300 bytes, which corresponds to an expansion rate of 33%.
The resulting text occupies 400 bytes, which corresponds to an expansion rate of 33%.
The resulting text occupies 400 bytes, which corresponds to an expansion rate of 133%.

tema6.question: What HTTP request headers are involved to implement conditional GETS, which only return the content of a file if it has been modified compared to the one in the client cache?
What is the main benefit introduced by QUIC, which is the base of HTTP/3?

answers.answer: At the transport layer it is implemented on top of TCP, which allows for faster connection setup and lower transport latency.
At the transport layer it is implemented on top of UDP, which allows to implement enhanced request multiplexing and congestion control.
At the transport layer it is implemented on top of TCP, which allows to implement enhanced request multiplexing and congestion control.

tema6.question: In the process of fetching a web page from a server, how many RTTs does the HTTP request/response process take?

Which transport layer does the FTP protocol used to send data between the client and the server?
In FTP, whcih range of response phase codes is used indicate positive completion?
In FTP, which command is used to navigate to a different directory on the remote server?
In FTP, what is the command used to upload a file from a client to a remote server?
In FTP, what is the purpose of the ASCII transfer mode?

answers.answer: To allow encyrpting the data to provide security.
To compress files and improve data transfer speeds.
To transfer text files and perform newline conversions.

tema6.question: Which of the following sentences regarding the FTP protocol is correct?

answers.answer: The FTP protocol uses UDP at the transport layer.
The FTP protocol uses in-band signaling for control.
The FTP protocol the data connection is persistent.
None of the sentences is correct.
